entry.title: How to set up Withholding Tax in Treasury Using Extended Withholding Tax
entry.content:
This blog describes setup of the withholding tax using integration from SAP Treasury and Risk Management (treasury) to the extended withholding tax in Financial Accounting. Besides the calculation and accounting this integration also ensures that corresponding withholding tax information is added to the resulting accounting documents. Such documents are included in standard legal reports in a given country. There are also other possibilities to calculate and account withholding taxes, e.g. using derived flows, however the resulting documents usually lack all the necessary withholding tax information.

Pre-delivered configuration in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud enables posting to supplier. However, this example scenario covers withholding tax on incoming interests in money market instruments posted to customer to describe all configuration steps. 

We focus on the configuration and master data related to withholding tax, we expect that you have already completed general setup for treasury and for the extended withholding tax in Financial Accounting.

 

1          Customizing Prerequisites

The withholding tax code and tax type are defined in Financial Accounting.

If the withholding tax code is defined as Payment Time, the system generates the withholding tax only at the time of payment in the transaction F110 (Automatic Payment). In this case, treasury generates only an empty flow and a corresponding item for table WITH_ITEM with withholding tax base amount.

If the withholding tax code is defined as Invoice Time, the system generates the withholding tax line item in the accounting document of the interest. Treasury then generates a flow with withholding tax amount.

 

2          Customizing in Treasury

2.1       Define Update Type for Withholding Tax

In our example we use update type TAXWH01.

2.2       Define Account Determination for Interest

The extended withholding tax requires posting to supplier/customer, therefore it is necessary to set up account determination for interest in treasury accordingly.

2.2.1     Posting Specification

It contains document type for posting on customer and GL account. The posting key for debit entry is for customer, and the account symbol has posting category for subledger posting in payment currency.

2.2.2     Assign Update Type to Posting Specification

It is important to mark the indication Payment Transaction in the assignment of the update type to posting specification.

2.3       Specify Flow Attributes for Extended Withholding Tax

In this activity we assign the withholding tax update type to the interest update type.

Note. Only maintain key fields that are relevant for the actual interest flow. If you maintain securities account for interest from money market instrument, the configuration won’t be selected in the processing, because money market instrument doesn’t carry securities account.

If you have a scenario with interest for securities do not maintain transaction type, because interests in securities account management (transaction TPM40) don’t carry transaction type.

The assignment also contains the withholding tax type and withholding tax code.

 

3          Business Partner Master Data

The withholding tax data are maintained in the corresponding tab Customer: Withholding Tax        

Note that the withholding tax and withholding tax code must be same as in the activity Specify Flow Attributes for Extended Withholding Tax. Also, the indicator withholding tax agent must be set.

 

4         Processing of the financial transaction

4.1       Create Financial Transaction

Enter the money market transaction as usual. On payment details page, it is crucial that the interest is posted to customer and without payment request:

 

The generated planned withholding tax isn’t visible directly under the Cash Flow tab. You can check it in the transaction TPM13 Treasury Position Flows – Classic

Note that this is only planned withholding tax. In some cases, the withholding tax can depend on some limits related to the business partner, and so the resulting withholding tax at the time of posting can differ. The cash flow in TPM13 serves as a good indication whether everything is set up correctly and the withholding tax is generated.

4.2       Post financial transaction

The withholding tax is posted together with the interest in the transaction TBB1 (Fix, Pay, and Post Flows). There is a limitation in posting log, which puts withholding tax in two-line items, whereas resulting accounting document has only one line item for withholding tax.

For more information about the basic settings for withholding tax, see Withholding Tax in Treasury.

entry.title: Simulation for SAM4U Solution: Flexibility with the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption
entry.content:
When adopting SAP SAM4U, one of the biggest challenges customers face is handling role, profile, and authorization changes without disrupting production. This is where the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings real value, thanks to its simulation capabilities.

What Customers Expect from Authorization Simulation

With the simulation, customers get the ability to:

  • Log changes at the role or profile level on the system dataset.
  • Track and review roles and profiles that have been modified.
  • Revert changes at the role or profile level, either all at once or individually.
  • Modify user-to-role or user-to-profile assignments.
  • Perform mass unassignments of roles and profiles (e.g., removing SAP_ALL or SAP_NEW).
  • Identify and review changes made to users.
  • Revert user assignments back to their original state when needed.

 Pic. 01 Roles and Profiles Changes Tracking

 Pic. 02 Roles and Profiles Mass Unassignment

 Pic. 03 Changes to the Role Detailed Review

But that’s not all! The real power lies in managing simulation snapshots.

 Pic. 04 Snapshots of Simulations on the System’s Dataset Level

Why Simulation Snapshots Matter

Simulation snapshots are created at the system dataset level, allowing you to:

  • Save changes without applying them directly in production.
  • Create new consolidations from modified datasets.
  • Avoid repetitive, time-consuming rework when changes cannot be applied immediately.

Example: Working with Two Systems in Consolidation

Imagine you are analyzing two systems in a consolidation project. You make changes to roles and users in both systems. However, due to restrictions, you cannot yet apply changes in System A.

Without losing your work, you can:

  • Create a new consolidation using the dataset from System A and the modified snapshot from System B.
  • Or temporarily move the snapshot from System A into the dataset, and later reapply those changes when they are ready for production.

 Pic. 05 The Power of Management Snapshots and Datasets that are Used in Consolidation

This flexibility ensures you never have to redo your work and can manage changes efficiently.

Why Customers Prefer the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption

Customers appreciate the simulation feature because it provides:

  • System-level flexibility to manage changes.
  • Easy-to-handle snapshots that can be created, reviewed, reverted, and reused.
  • No duplication of effort, once a change is made, it is saved and can be reapplied.
  • Reliable validation, you can reload fresh production data and check if changes were successfully implemented.

If changes were tracked only at the consolidation level, fresh data from the system would overwrite them. This is why the Accelerator focuses on system snapshots, giving customers full control to experiment, validate, and roll back whenever needed.

 Pic.06 Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption Dashboard for Simulation Results Analysis

With the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, simulation becomes not just a test environment, but a strategic tool for efficient and risk-free SAM4U adoption.

entry.title: Understanding Release Contracts (C0–C3) in S/4HANA Repository Objects
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog is the first in a short series about extension and API stability in S/4HANA. In this post I’ll explain release contracts (also known as stability contracts) — what they are, why SAP uses them, and how they affect the objects you work with every day.

A Release Contract is a classification that indicates how stable a repository object is and how it can be used or extended. It’s SAP’s formal promise that certain objects will remain stable across upgrades. The goal is to strike a balance: on one hand, SAP keeps the system flexible so development can continue; on the other, key technical elements are kept stable so consumers don’t need to rewrite code after every upgrade.

To provide those guarantees, SAP defines different stability/release contracts (C0, C1, C2, …). Each contract describes the intended scope of use — for example, whether something is intended as a safe extension point, a stable in-system API, or a remote API for external callers.

Stability Contracts

       C0 : Contract for Extensions

       C1 : Contract for System Internal Use

       C2 : Contract for Remote API Use

       C3 : Manage Configuration Content

       C4 : Use in ABAP Managed Database Procedure ( Not covered in this blog )

Let us look at how these Contracts apply to comman repository Objects.

CDS Views : CDS views are one of the most common repository objects you’ll come across in S/4HANA. SAP uses release contracts to make clear whether a CDS view can be extended, consumed inside the system, or even exposed to the outside world.

  • C0 - Extend

    • A C0 contract means the CDS view can be safely extended
    • There are two main ways to extend
      • Key user Extensibility : add your own custom fields (or sometimes even make standard fields available) using the Custom Fields app in FIORI.
      • Developer Extensibility : Use ABAP Development Tools (ADT) to create a CDS view extension. This lets you add fields or annotations to the view in a controlled way.
    • The promise here is that the structure of the view won’t change in a way that breaks your code across upgrades.

            

  • C1 - System Internal Use

    • A C1 contract means the CDS view is a stable API for internal consumption.

    • You can safely use a C1 released CDS in :
      • Key user Extensibility : For Analytical Queries, Custom CDS Views
      • Developer Extensibility : In Custom ABAP code in ABAP Cloud or S/4 HANA Cloud.
    • In both cases, the base CDS view provides stable “anchors” where your extensions will survive upgrades.

          

  • C2 - Remote APIs

    • Sometimes the data in a CDS view isn’t just needed internally, but also by external systems.

    • In those cases, SAP exposes the CDS via an OData service (or other service binding).
    • When a CDS view is published for remote consumption, it carries a C2 contract. This ensures the external API is technically stable for side-by-side or third-party integrations.

                

 

Database Tables : Database tables are the lowest-level repository objects in the system. In Practice SAP most often delivers these with C3 ( Manage Configuration Content ).

Tables can also be prepared by the provider for C0 ( Developer Extensibility ) using specific Annotation and release state settings - but this is an opt-in decision design. Most standard tables are not exposed this way , because SAP prefers that extensions happen via CDS views.

The release contract you’ll find for tables is C3 – Manage Configuration Content.

  • C3 - Manage Configuration Content

    • A C3 contract means the table is intended for storing configuration data (for example, customizing or setup values).
    • With C3, SAP promises that the persistence and structure of the table will remain stable so that tools can reliably export, import, or transport configuration across systems.
  • Why Not C0 or C1 for tables ?
    • No C1: Tables are not meant to be consumed directly in ABAP Cloud development. If you need business data, you should always go through a released CDS view
    • C0 possible but rare : SAP does allow tables to be released with C0 if explicitly enabled by the provider (using annotations), but most delivered tables are not. Instead, SAP recommends CDS views or the Custom Fields app for extensibility. 

          

 

Behavior Defination ( RAP Business Object ) : Behavior definitions describe what you can do with a business object in RAP (the RESTful ABAP Programming Model) — things like creating, updating, deleting, running validations, or triggering actions. 

Unlike CDS views, most SAP-delivered behavior definitions are released with C1 (System-Internal Use). A C0 contract for behavior definitions is technically possible (the framework supports it if the provider enables extension anchors), but in practice it is rare. You should always check the API State in ADT to see what’s allowed.

  • C1 - System Internal Use

    • A C1 contract means the business object is safe to consume inside the system, but not open for developer extensions. 
    • You Can :
      • Call the BO’s actions and operations in your own ABAP Cloud code.
      • Bind the BO to a Fiori Elements app and use it in your custom applications.
      • Rely on its structure to remain stable across upgrades.

 

Conclusion

This blog focused on SAP-delivered objects and how SAP marks their stability (C0–C3): CDS views (C0 for extension, C1 for in-system use, C2 for remote APIs), behavior definitions (generally C1 for consumption; C0 only if explicitly enabled), and database tables (commonly C3 for configuration; tables can also be prepared for C0, but that is opt-in).. Although there are other blogs that go deep into specific object types, this post is meant as a pre-read to give you the holistic view. And if you want to actually find released objects and their contracts, the magic lies in the System Library in ADT — and how you configure the tree.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Integration with SAP S/4HANA: SAP Cloud Connector Setup Guide
entry.content:
Introduction: 

In this article, we will explore SAP Cloud Connector what it is, its purpose, and the scenarios where it becomes essential. Whether you are working with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud or connecting SAP S/4HANA on-premise systems to the cloud, the SAP Cloud Connector plays a critical role. We will also provide a step-by-step guide on its configuration and setup, helping you seamlessly bridge your on-premise and SAP Datasphere cloud environments.

What is SAP Cloud Connector?

The SAP Cloud Connector acts as a secure link between SAP Datasphere and on-premises systems, enabling seamless integration without exposing your entire internal network (behind the firewall). It runs as an on-premises agent or middleware in a secured environment and functions as a reverse invoke proxy, providing controlled access to selected systems and resources. 

Key benefits include fine-grained control over which on-premises systems cloud applications can access, automatic recovery of broken connections, and audit logging of inbound traffic and configuration changes. It also supports high-availability setups for enterprise scenarios.

Compared to opening firewall ports or using DMZ reverse proxies, the Cloud Connector is easier and safer to deploy. It supports multiple protocols, including HTTP and RFC for native ABAP system access, and allows secure propagation of cloud user identities to on-premises systems. With simple installation, low TCO, and standard SAP support, it’s an efficient solution for connecting cloud and on-premises landscapes.

Does it support data encryption ?

Yes, TLS encryption is used for the tunnel

What are the SAP Datasphere data integration features, and in which scenarios is the SAP Cloud Connector required?

  • Replication Flows – For example, connecting to SAP ABAP CDS views and replicating data to the cloud.
  • Data Flows – For scenarios like extracting, transforming, and loading data from on-premises sources, including SAP ABAP CDS views.
  • Model Import – Importing existing ABAP CDS data models from on-premises systems into SAP Datasphere for further analytics and integration.

SAP Cloud Connector FAQs

Where can I find information about SAP Cloud Connector licensing, downloading, and installation ?

  • 2827108 - SAP Cloud Connector licensing, download and installation information.
  • It does not required separate license and it is free to use.
  • Download: SAP Cloud Connector.
  • Installation and Setup.

What are the Sizing Recommendations? 

  • Sizing for the Master Instance
  • Sizing for the Shadow Instance

What are the best practices and recommendations for setting up SAP Cloud Connector?

  • Always Use the Latest Version: Install or update to the latest Cloud Connector release to take advantage of new features and security improvements.
  • Dedicated Server Setup: Install on a dedicated server within your corporate network that has direct, unblocked access to the source system. Ideally, this server should be physically close to the source systems it connects to.
  • High Availability Setup:
    • Master (Primary Installation): Main Cloud Connector instance for normal or HA setups.
    • Shadow (Backup Installation): Secondary instance for HA, providing failover support.
  • Environment-Specific Installations: recommended to have a separate Cloud Connector for each environment (development, testing, production) to ensure stability and isolation.
  • User Configuration: Use an email ID linked to the subaccount or global account instead of an S-User for easier management.
  • Proper Sizing: Ensure the server has sufficient resources (CPU, memory, network bandwidth) to handle the expected load.
  • Regular Log Review: Continuously monitor logs and metrics to detect performance issues or connectivity problems and resolve them promptly.

SAP Cloud Connector Troubleshooting Guides:

  • Common Issues and Guided Answers.
  • Logs and Troubleshooting.
  • 3369433 - How to troubleshoot Cloud Connector related issues when creating connection in SAP Datasphere

Steps to Install, Configure and Setup the SAP Cloud Connector:

Step 1: Download, Prerequisites, and Install the Cloud Connector

Before you begin configuration, make sure the following prerequisites are in place:

  • Download: SAP Cloud Connector.
  • The Cloud Connector is installed in your on-premise network. (See Cloud Connector Installation in the SAP BTP Connectivity documentation.)
  • If you’re using egress firewalling, add these domains to the firewall/proxy allowlist:
    •  *.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    • *.k8s-hana.ondemand.com
  • You need an SAP BTP account. If you don’t already have one, create it by registering in the SAP BTP cockpit.

Step 2: Launch and Login

  • After installation, an user:Administrator account is created with the initial password: manage (case-sensitive). You’ll be prompted to change it on first login. Default/Initial login details Administrator / manage 

  • Access the Cloud Connector Administration at:
    https://<hostname>:8443 (replace <hostname> with the machine name, or use localhost if installed locally).

  • 2388242 - KBA: How to reset SAP Cloud Connector built-in user's password

Step 3: Add Your SAP BTP Subaccount

You’ll need details from your SAP Datasphere subaccount:

  • Subaccount

  • Region Host ( Data Center - Providers and Regions)

  • Sub Account User (usually the email ID tied to your BTP account)

If account info is missing, enter your SAP BTP user ID manually. For troubleshooting, see KBA: 2397165.

2571763 - Authorization problem in SAP Cloud Connector when adding Cloud Foundry subaccount

For auth errors refer Log and Trace Files: scc_core.trc

Note: Initially SAP BTP Core account details in SAP Datasphere will not be available, you must provide the SAP BTP account email and save. SAP Datasphere tenant owner can perform this.

 

 

Step 4: Verify Connection

Once the subaccount is added, the status should display Connected.

 

Step 5: Configure the Cloud Connector

For this guide, we’ll focus on Replication Flow scenarios using RFC and HTTPS protocols.

 

Step 6: Add the SAP S/4HANA (ABAP) System

  1. Select Cloud to On-Premise scenario and Back-end Type: ABAP System.

     

  2. Choose HTTPS protocol.

     

  3. Use without load balancing (application server + instance number).

     

  4. Enter your SAP S/4HANA internal host and port.

    How to find internal host and port from SAP S/4HANA ? (Run T-Code SMICM → Services).

     

  5. Leaving defaults for principal propagation and system certificate. (check your requirement and change)

     

  6. Define a virtual host name (recommended: different from the internal name).

     

     

  7. Provide a System ID (e.g., RI4) and description, then finish setup.

     

  8. Test connectivity – status should show Reachable.

     

  9. Add resources – in this scenario, we added all resources under /.

     

Step 7: Add RFC Protocol Resources

  1. Select RFC protocol.

     

  2. Enter system mapping details (System ID + description).

     

  3. Finish setup and test connectivity.

     

      

  4. Map required resources:

     

    • With Prefix (e.g., DHAMB_)

        

    • With Exact Name (e.g., RFC_FUNCTION_SEARCH)

       

  5. Ensure the status turns Green for all resources.

     

Step 8: Maintain IP Allow list in SAP Datasphere

  1. Identify the public IP address of the host where Cloud Connector is installed (e.g., via whatismyip.com or ip.me or whatever way you are aware of).

     

  2. Add this IP under Trusted Cloud Connector IPs in SAP Datasphere:
    System → Configuration → IP Allowlist.

     

Step 9: Maintain the Cloud Connector Location ID in SAP Datasphere

Go to:
SAP Datasphere →System → Administration → Data Source Configuration and maintain the Cloud Connector Location ID.

 

 

With these steps completed, your SAP Cloud Connector is successfully installed, connected, and configured to integrate and create a native connection type of SAP S/4HANA on-premise with SAP Datasphere.

Summary: 

In this blog, we saw how the SAP Cloud Connector helps connect SAP Datasphere with on-premise systems in a secure and easy way. It supports features like Replication Flows, Data Flows, and Model Import for smooth data integration. We also looked at the benefits such as simple setup, better security, high availability, and low cost. With best practices like keeping it updated, using a dedicated server, and regular monitoring, you can ensure reliable performance. Finally, we walked through the step-by-step setup to successfully link SAP S/4HANA with SAP Datasphere.

entry.title: Plant abroad scenario of Inbound Message Handler for Poland solution
entry.content:
This blog post is intended to describe the enablement of plant abroad scenario of Inbound Message Handler on both SAP S/4HANA and SAP ERP releases for Poland.

PLEASE NOTE: the plant abroad scenario can only be executed when the company code belongs to a different country if compared to the country assigned to the message type.


Disclaimer: The plant abroad scenario only works if the new features of Inbound Message Handler are activated. Please check below:

In SAP S/4HANA and SAP ERP

SM30 → EDOGENCUSTV

Country-specific steps to be executed

Steps to be executed by either country teams or customer inhouse developers *

In  SAP S/4HANA and SAP ERP

Create/edit an entry for the new/existing message type:

S4H OP 2023 and 2022

S4H 2021 and lower

EDOM

SM30 → EDOMSGTYPEV

Assign it to the country, select the Message Group "Pulling" , Message Type "PL_KSEF_QRY_MSG_PULL" and "PL_KSEF_SESSION_PULL" and flag the “Plant abroad” checkbox:

EDOM:

 

SM30 → EDOMSGTYPEV

 

Inbound Message Handler Report (TA EDOC_INBOUND_MSG)

The flag becomes available for use and the scenario can be executed.

This is how you enable the plants abroad scenario for Poland in the Inbound Message Handler.

entry.title: Embedded Finance in SAP: SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity with J.P. Morgan Payments
entry.content:
Enterprises are rethinking how to connect banking capabilities with ERP processes to maximize business value. Key questions include:

  • How to make payments, reconciliation, and cash visibility seamless and fully integrated between banks and the ERP system?
  • How to adopt innovations like real-time payments or real-time cash balances without launching a new IT project every time a banking service gets added?
  • How to unlock the combined value of invoice and payment data in the ERP alongside the cash and financial data held by banks?

SAP and J.P. Morgan asked themselves the same questions. And as a result decided to collaborate and partner even closer to bring more value to shared clients by better integrating the capabilities of both by accelerating adoption of SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC) to deliver J.P. Morgan bank services embedded in ERP processes.

With SAP MBC, corporates get direct, standardized access to J.P. Morgan banking services directly integrated into their payment and cash processes. As a result corporates can scale new services faster, without custom builds and with minimal ongoing maintenance and benefit from the seamless and many times real time data flow to get the decision advantage crucial in todays fast and ever changing business world.

What you can expect

  • Seamless connectivity: Integrate J.P. Morgan services via SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity to connect your SAP ERP to J.P. Morgan Payments using standardized, bank-approved channels.
  • Automate payments and reporting: The J.P. Morgan Payments Adapter 2.0 supports file-based payments (ACH, checks, virtual cards, wires—including FX) and real-time payments across the U.S., EU, UK, Australia, Singapore, Malaysia, and Hong Kong.
  • Real-time insights: Access instant reporting and reconciliation, view account balances and transaction details, and track payments through advanced APIs.
  • Easy implementation: Prebuilt adapters and help you go live quickly and securely
  • AI-powered treasury: Leverage SAP’s cloud data foundation and AI-driven capabilities to interact with J.P. Morgan and elevate treasury operations.

Who can benefit

  • New and existing J.P. Morgan clients using SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud, Private Cloud, or On-Premise) or SAP ECC (6.0+)
  • Organizations operating on J.P. Morgan Access, with support for multi-bank reporting across non–J.P. Morgan DDAs
  • Teams seeking flexible connection options through SAP MBC to tailor integrations to specific business needs

This collaboration meets clients where they are simplifying connectivity while strengthening control and visibility at the same time, and accelerating access to new banking innovations, all embedded in SAP ERP processes.

Want to know more?

  • SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity 
    • https://www.sap.com/germany/products/financial-management/multi-bank-connectivity.html 
    • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_MULTI_BANK_CONNECTIVITY
  • J.P. Morgan SAP Integration:
    • https://partners.jpmorgan.com/sap_s4hana.html
  • SAP and J.P. Morgan Partnership:
    • https://digital.jpmorgan.com/jpmorgan-with-sap/index.html

Still want to know more?

Meet us at the AFP Conference in Boston on October 26–29 or attend SAP and J.P. Morgan session at the AFP and J.P. Morgan Booth on Tuesday Oct 28th  2-2.30pm local Boston time

entry.title: Introducing the WalkMe-based alternative in-app help user experience: What and How to Activate
entry.content:
Good news! With the 2508 upgrade, SAP has released 12 standard, non-customizable WalkMe flows, ideal for accountants and sales representatives (no extra license; activation needed). 

SAP recently acquired WalkMe, which is a digital adoption platform that overlays your application to guide users how to navigate workflows step-by-step. Think of it as a tutorial with little bubbles that pop up and tell users where to click and what to input in fields when they're trying to complete a process, like create a sales order. 

Turn this on once and your users get step‑by‑step help in 33 languages* for high‑impact sales and finance tasks: Sales (Find/Edit/Create Order, Set Delivery Block, Add Shipping Instructions), Finance (Find/Change/Reverse/Copy Journal Entry, Customize Line Item View, View Related Documents), plus a homepage tour. These Smart Walk-Thrus are especially helpful to new users who need in-app guidance. Subject to change.

Persona

Embedded Flows

Apps in Scope

 General Accountant

  • Find a Journal Entry
  • Customize Line Item View
  • Change Line Item in a Journal Entry
  • Reverse Journal Entry
  • Copy a Journal Entry
  • View related documents in a Journal Entry

Manage Journal Entries - New Version (F0717A)

 Sales Rep

  • Create a Sales Order
  • Find a Sales Order
  • Edit a Sales Order
  • Set a Delivery Block
  • Add Shipping Instructions

Manage Sales Order - Version 2 (F3893)

 All Personas

  • Welcome to My Home

MyHome

 
*For more information like the available languages, please see SAP Note 3609634.

Note: If you are using SAP Enable Now, the WalkMe-based alternative in-app help user experience or WalkMe Premium is not available.

Activate (2–3 minutes): 

  1. Replace "Shell-home" with "#Shell-startGUI?sap-ui2-tcode=FTG_EXTERNAL" in the URL address to reach the configuration page within your customizing tenant (development/quality). This is a quick shortcut to reach the configuration activity page.
    1. Alternatively, navigate step-by-step to the configuration activity page:
      1. 2SL Customers with SB: Navigate to app "Manage Your Solution" -> Configure Your Solution -> Filter for "Application Area" - Application Platform and Infrastructure"; "Sub Application Area" - "General Settings" -> Basic Settings -> Configuration Steps -> Activate Features -> Configure
      2. 2SL & 3SL Customers with CBC: Navigate to app "Implementation Activities" -> General Settings-> Cross Application -> Activate New Features->Activate Features -> IMG Activity (clock with check symbol)

  2. Select feature: APS_UI_WME_INTEGRATION. Click 'Activate/Deactivate Feature' button near the top.
  3. Create/select transport if prompted. Name Transport to your liking. Close.
  4. Confirm State turns from red to green. Try the flows in dev before exporting to test and prod.

What happens next:

  • Open apps like Manage Journal Entries - New Version or Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 and click the question mark icon at the top of your page to open the WalkMe menu. Click on the Smart Walk Thrus under the Tours tab and you’ll see the bubbles guiding each step.
  • Notify the relevant users (ie. accountants and sales reps) how to find this and use this.

If you're interested in more WalkMe capabilities, like custom flows, analytics, and cross-app functionality (SAP and non-SAP apps), contact your SAP Customer Success Manager to find out more.

Have questions? Let’s chat in the comments!

entry.title: SAP MDG: Based on Grouping, Tax Number is Mandatory
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note: This blog does not include execution screenshots.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to make the Tax Number field mandatory for specific Groupings. The logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via BADI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY.

Prerequisite: A working knowledge of BADI USMD_RULE_SERVICE and ABAP development is required to follow this implementation.

Development Details

  • Target Groupings: ZSGP, ZSGC
  • Message Class: ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS
  • Message Number: 001
  • Message Type: E
  • Message Text: Tax Number is Mandatory !!!
  • BADI Method Implemented: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY 

    The validation logic is written directly in the method CHECK_ENTITY

    This ensures that when the specified groupings are selected, the system enforces the presence of a Tax Number and raises a custom message if it's missing.

Code:

 

  METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.
    CALL METHOD io_model->read_entity_data_all
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname    = 'BP_HEADER'            
        if_active      = abap_false            
        i_crequest     = id_crequest            " Change Request
      IMPORTING
        et_data_entity = DATA(lt_data).        " Data for Entity Types
    .
    READ TABLE lt_data INTO DATA(ls_data) WITH KEY usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = ' ' struct = 'KATTR'.
    ASSIGN ls_data-r_t_data->* TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lt_data>).
    LOOP AT <lt_data> ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_data>).
      ASSIGN COMPONENT 'BU_GROUP' OF STRUCTURE <ls_data> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_group>).
      IF <lv_group> IS ASSIGNED AND
         <lv_group> EQ 'ZSGP' OR
         <lv_group> EQ 'ZSGC'.
        READ TABLE lt_data INTO ls_data WITH KEY usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_TAXNUM' struct = 'KATTR'.
        IF sy-subrc <> 0.
          et_message = VALUE #( ( msgid = 'ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS' msgty = 'E' msgno = '001' ) ).
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.


SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Integrating SAP Datasphere with S/4HANA in ECS
entry.content:
Integrating SAP S/4 HANA with Datasphere in ECS:

Introduction

In today's data-driven business landscape, seamless integration between enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems and advanced analytics platforms is crucial for unlocking real-time insights and driving informed decision-making. SAP Datasphere, a cloud-based data management solution, offers powerful capabilities for data modelling, federation, and replication. SAP Datasphere integration enables SAP S/4HANA system and the organizations to harmonize data from core business operations with broader analytics workflows, all, while maintaining security and compliance.

Objective of this guide is to serve as a walkthrough guide for integrating S/4HANA system  with SAP Datasphere. However, please note that this guide is for information purpose only and the configuration steps in customers’ responsibility should be followed up by the customers accordingly.

Architecture Diagram

Prerequisites for Integration

Before diving into the setup, please note that, for the convenience of this guide and to be in sync with the terms, here on, we will assume S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition at ECS as S/4HANA system. Which also implies customer’s current landscape (when referred as on-premise) is ‘ECS’- a managed private cloud.

  1. SAP Datasphere Service Instance: Customer should have already completed the onboarding of SAP Datasphere. It runs on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
  2. Data Provisioning (DP) Agent:  Required for handling remote table data flow between on-premise and cloud. To be requested and have it provisioned accordingly.
  3. SAP Cloud Connector: Required to securely expose on-premise systems to the cloud without opening firewalls (reverse invoke) used for replication and live data flow connections. To be requested and have it provisioned accordingly.
  4. Network and Access: All applicable secure network connections between S/4HANA and Datasphere based on relevant dataflows to be taken care.
    Ex: CC for inbound dataflows from BTP to ECS and outbound internet proxy for outbound traffic from ECS to Datasphere. Also IP allowlisting for the DP Agent server and likewise.

4.1       IP allowlisting Process:

In order to connect ECS instance to datasphere tenant, it requires public IP associated with customer network’s internet proxy of the ECS servers to be added in IP allowlist tab in datasphere.

This is the public IP of their CGS proxy server. Customer can follow KBA 3643152 to get this public IP.

After getting this IP, log in to Datasphere tenant System  Configuration  IP Allowlist  Trusted Ips

 

  • SAP Notes and Add-ons: Implement relevant SAP Notes (e.g., 3283282 for CDS views, 3016862 for ABAP integration) in S/4HANA system and ensure the DMIS add-on is available for replication scenarios.
  • SICF services for live connection : Ensure all SICF services under the node /sap/bw/ina are activated in the S/4HANA system.
  • User Permissions: Administrative access in Datasphere, S/4HANA, and BTP

Integration Steps

The integration process involves configuring connectivity, setting up agents, and creating connections in Datasphere. Here's a detailed technical walkthrough

Step 1: Set Up Spaces in SAP Datasphere

  • Navigate to Space Management in Datasphere.
  • Create a new space and assign users to it. This space will host your data models and connections.

 

Step 2: Register and Configure the Data Provisioning Agent

  • In Datasphere, go to System > Configuration > Data Integration and create an On-Premise Agent.
  • Note the agent details: Name, HANA server (host), port, username, and password for messaging.
  • On the DP Agent server:
    • Run ./agentcli.sh –configAgent in the /usr/sap/<SID>/dataprovagent/bin directory.

    • Select SAP HANA Connection > 7. Connect to SAP Datasphere via JDBC.

 

  1. Specify the details according to information provided by customer:
  1. Name of the agent instance.
  2. Set " true" to use an encrypted connection over JDBC.
  3. Specify the hostname and port for the  SAP Datasphere  instance.
    • Hostname: <instance_name>.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    • Port Number: 443
  4. As SAP Datasphere is situated outside the ECS network infrastructure, a proxy is required for HTTPS communication. Define the default CGS proxy host - proxy:3128 (no authentication required)
  5. Provide the authentication credentials for the HANA User for Agent Messaging.
  6.  Confirm to save the agent connection settings. With that any existing agent connection settings are overwritten.

  • Restart the DP Agent.
  • Enable required adapters (e.g., ABAPAdapter for S/4HANA).

 

Step 3: Configure SAP Cloud Connector

  • To configure cloud connector we need the information of Datasphere’s internal Subaccount details. This can be found under Datasphere tenant, System  Administration Data source Configuration  SAP BTP Core Account

        

 

  • If the email ID which will be used to setup cloud connector is not visible under the Subaccount User header, use the Change/Add Cloud Platform User option to the respective ID.
  • Under the Live Data Sources header select the ‘Allow live data to securely leave my network’ option
  • Under On-Premise Data Sources header add the location ID you will be using in your cloud connector if any.

 

  • Add the subaccount in Cloud connector using the Subaccount ID, Region Host and user information from above.
  • Add the same location ID as configured in the previous step.

  • Add your on-premise S/4HANA system in the Cloud Connector:
    • Use HTTPS and RFC protocols.
    • System type: ABAP.
    • For HTTPS “/” URL path needs to be exposed for all Paths and Sub-Paths
    • For RFC protocol add resources as below-
      • ‘DHAMB_’ and ‘DHAPE_’ with prefix for CDS view extraction.
      • ‘LTAMB_’ and ‘LTAPE_’ with prefix option for accessing tables with SLT.
      • ‘/SAPDS/’ with prefix option for accessing data with ODP.
      • Add RFC_FUNCTION_SEARCH with exact name option for all three options.
  • Ensure both RFC and HTTPS resources are reachable.

Step 4: Prepare S/4HANA for Connectivity

  • Create a TCP/IP RFC connection in S/4HANA using program ID IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER.
  • Register the program at the OS level: rfcexec -a IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER -g <Hostname> -x SAPGW<Instance no.> -s <SID> &.
  • Test the RFC connection.

Step 5: Create the Connection in SAP Datasphere to S/4H

To create live data connection from datasphere to backend S4 system in ECS, it uses SSH tunnel via Cloud connector

In your Datasphere space, select System > Configuration  Data Integration.

  • Go to Live Data Connections (Tunnel) click on “Manage Live Data Connections”  A window opens click on “+” a pop up opens, select SAP S/4 HANA

  • For live data: using a Tunnel connection enter the Location ID maintained in Cloud connector
  • Input application server details, system number, client ID, SID,
  • Provide S/4HANA username and password.

 

 

 

After you click on Ok it adds the connection

 

Step 6: Set Up Data Flows and Models

  • Use Remote Tables for federation or Replication Flows for data replication (supporting initial and delta loads via CDC).
  • Import CDS views using the Model Import Wizard to automatically bring in metadata and semantics.

entry.title: SAP Commerce Cloud Q3 ‘25 Release Highlights
entry.content:
In the third quarter of 2025, SAP Commerce Cloud introduced key enhancements designed to improve conversion, accelerate innovation, and empower data-driven decision making. Discover new AI-powered capabilities, enhancements to SAP Order Management Services, and SQL View Gateway.

We invite you to explore these SAP Commerce Cloud updates from the last three months by joining our Q3 2025 Release Highlights webcast to stay updated on our latest advancements.

We have the Customer Experience Connect event next week, where we showcase how the latest AI-infused SAP CX solutions optimize operations, generate action-ready insights, and deliver delightful experiences at every step of the customer journey.

Also, check out the Q3 release from the entire SAP CX portfolio.

Now, on to the SAP Commerce Cloud highlights from Q3 2025.

Insightful

Smarter recommendations with real-time stock visibility

The AI-based Shopping Agent now has product stock awareness to allow merchants to configure if out of stock products are displayed in the product recommendations that the Shopping Agent returns. This can lower abandoned carts and improves the customer experience when shoppers know an item is in stock.

Merchants can also configure if they want to allow answering questions about bulk quantities being in stock, an important feature for B2B transactions. The real-time stock visibility increases transparency, boosting conversions with relevant recommendations and improving customer trust.

Check stock on bulk quantities with Shopping Agent

Intelligently optimize catalogs for conversion

Leverage AI to quickly update product information, such as attributes or descriptions, based on system triggers or changes. The Catalog Optimization Agent also reviews product images and recommends enhancements. As a safeguard, a human is in the loop to review the recommendations and publish back to the Commerce catalog.

The Catalog Optimization Agent improves discoverability and conversions, while reducing the manual effort in editing product descriptions.

Settings for Catalog Optimization Agent

 

Connected

Empowering Unified Commerce with Central Order Service

The release of Central Order Service for SAP Order Management Foundation introduces a robust foundation for Unified Commerce, seamlessly integrating online and offline transactions. This paves the way for omnichannel scenarios like BORIS (Buy Online, Return in Store) and BISRO (Buy in Store, Return Online), offering greater flexibility in the customer experience.

 

Additionally, the Central Order Service empowers businesses with a comprehensive 360-degree view of customer purchase histories, enhancing personalization and customer engagement.

 

The rollout of API V3 for SAP Order Management Foundation significantly enhances the solution's performance and scalability, ensuring that it meets the dynamic needs of modern commerce.

 

Automatically push real-time product availability updates to external systems

The Availability Push feature in SAP Order Management for Sourcing and Availability enables proactive delivery of real-time product availability updates to external systems, such as web shops and marketplaces.  

 

This ensures that these external systems always have the latest stock information, reducing the risk of order cancellations due to outdated data. Tailored updates can be configured based on specific channels, products, and frequency, allowing for efficient communication by sending only changes in stock levels.

 

Increase data accuracy and ERP compliance

The Type Code feature for SAP Omnichannel Sales Transfer and Audit implements a robust validation process for ERP type codes, ensuring that only valid codes are transmitted to the ERP system. Each customer can configure a list of acceptable type codes, preventing invalid codes from being processed and halting transactions until corrections are made by an auditor.

 

The feature includes a user interface that facilitates the configuration of valid codes, default settings for critical fields, and options for handling optional fields without triggering false validation errors. Invalid type codes will be flagged as critical errors, and clear, actionable error messages will guide users in correcting discrepancies. Additionally, this system accommodates customer-specific mappings and customizable settings, promoting accuracy and reducing transaction-related issues.


Ensure only validated, customer-specific type codes flow into your ERP with flexible configuration and transparent error handling, resulting in fewer transaction failures, streamlined audits, and improved operational efficiency.

Adaptive

Data Unlocked: Fast, Secure, and Flexible SQL Access for SAP Commerce Cloud

With SQL View Gateway, customers gain self-service access to SAP Commerce Cloud data for efficient analytics, reporting, and integrations—accelerating insights and driving smarter business outcomes.

Our new real-time database replicas provide you with direct SQL access that let you build dashboards, enable internal workflows, send information to Data Lakes and more, without affecting your Production database.

You will be able to manage who can access data, the scope of data available, and introduce full separation by creating up to 20 different replicas with independently scaled computes, URLs, IP Filters and authorizations.

SQL View Gateway is provided as a self-service option in the Cloud Portal that you can purchase through Consumption Credits.

 

SQL View Gateway

New APIs Drive Greater Self-Service Efficiency

Scaling Configuration API for sandboxes enables automated scaling and consumption credit savings. The API provides more control for tech-savvy DevOps teams while reducing repetitive Cloud Portal work and possibility for errors. It can retrieve the current scaling, schedule actions such as hibernating or waking environments, and enable scripts to enforce off-hours policies.

Cloud Portal API saves time and can scale dozens of endpoints without added effort. The API exposes endpoint configurations, including Maintenance Mode, for programmatic control. Customers now have API-based automation to turn maintenance on/off for every endpoint in an environment.

SSL Certificate Management API allows for faster operations, fewer mistakes, lower outage risk, and scalable governance. By integrating with your CA/SCM and updating endpoints via API, there are no more manual swaps. Automating the management of SSL certificates is safer and less prone to mistakes.

Framework Update release

We are pleased to announce the availability of the Framework Update with the September 2025 update release! Gain access to the latest functionality provided by Java 21 and Spring 6, while running the most secure and high-performance version of SAP Commerce Cloud. This is compatible with the Composable Storefront update that was released at the same time.

Please register for the SAP Commerce Cloud Tech-Focused Update webcast on October 22 for more details on this and other topics.

For more details on the above release features, check out the following resources:

  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Ready Kit
  • Performance Optimization Best Practices
  • SAP Commerce Cloud update cycle
  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Navigator single access point to release content

SAP Help Portal

  • SAP Commerce Cloud What’s New

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Commerce Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‑centric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points – like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations – go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances – short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted – and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you’re moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it’s crucial to have full transparency into what’s actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it’s difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product’s environmental footprint – enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action – whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms – survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center – delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it’s routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

 

 

Onboarding Booster

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we’re speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. Once these steps are confirmed, the system takes over and performs the necessary configurations in the background. The result is a fully prepared environment that is ready for role assignment and productive use. This is more than just a time saver, it reduces complexity and lowers the barrier for customers to get started quickly and confidently. For detailed guidance, the full procedure is documented in our Help Portal: Setting Up Using Booster.

 

Other Release Highlights

We’ve redesigned the SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure for a more intuitive experience. New app groups offer logical organization, simplifying navigation and helping you to quickly find what you need. For more information, see Enhanced SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure.

You can now assign different location types (not just plants) to a single business activity, expanding flexibility, supporting more accurate form generation, and ensuring that business activities can be valid across multiple locations. See Creating Business Activities for more information.

Additionally, when setting your footprint inventory scope, plant assignments now ensure that only relevant forms are generated for your selected companies and locations. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

 

Customer Success Stories

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. These solutions consolidated over 200 sustainability metrics from across the business, delivering advanced carbon footprint calculations at both product and corporate levels. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their “now4tomorrow” program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Read the full story: Getting ahead of regulatory reporting to steer business process transformation.

Tyrolit is a global leader in abrasive tools and construction systems that operates across 48 companies and exports to 140+ countries. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. Check the full story: Tooling up to unlock the sustainable value chain with a robust ESG data foundation.

 

Upcoming Partner Webinars

Staying ahead means staying informed, and this quarter again brings two opportunities exclusively for our partners to connect and learn more about SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Both webinars are free for partners with a valid SAP Learning Hub license.

The SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training is a biannual event designed to empower partners with in-depth product know-how, practical guidance, and the latest innovations across SAP Cloud ERP, the SAP Business Suite, AI-powered features, and more. On October 10, you can learn more about the latest updates in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange. Register for the session here: Sustainability Management and Carbon Accounting. For an overview of all sessions and their respective registration links check out: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025.

On November 5, the Meet the Expert Session returns. This highly interactive webinar is your chance to bring questions directly to the SAP experts from the Product Management and Customer Adoption teams. Gain practical insights, obtain answers to your questions, and deepen your expertise in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Register here: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management - Meet the Expert Q4 2025.

 

Additional Information

To learn more on how you can enhance the accuracy of your Scope 3.1 emissions reporting by transitioning from broad average data to precise, supplier-specific actuals, you should check out the blog post Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1 by @CButzlaff. This article outlines a practical, phased approach for implementing this strategy using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

For a comprehensive guide on how to embed carbon accounting into your ERP and finance processes, have a look into the new SAP PRESS book Carbon Accounting for Sustainability with SAP. It explains how to capture sustainability data across your ERP landscape, calculate product- and company-level carbon footprints, and integrate results into finance through SAP Green Ledger. You’ll also learn how SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management enable accurate, auditable carbon data for decision-making and reporting.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: SAP MDG: Validation - No Special Characters in Account Holder Field
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to restrict the use of special characters in the Account Holder field. The validation logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via BADI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY. This ensures data consistency and compliance with formatting standards during master data creation and change processes.

Prerequisite: A working knowledge of BADI USMD_RULE_SERVICE and ABAP development is required to follow this implementation.

Development Details

  • Message Class: ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS
  • Message Number: 002
  • Message Type: E
  • Message Text: The Account Holder field must not contain any special characters
  • BADI Method Implemented: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY 

    The validation logic is written directly in the method CHECK_ENTITY

    This ensures that when the Account Holder field is entered, the system validates the content to ensure it does not contain any special characters, and raises a custom message if invalid characters are found

Code:

 METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.
   DATA: lt_data        TYPE usmd_ts_data_entity,
         lt_bank_data   TYPE REF TO data,
         lt_msg         TYPE usmd_t_message,
         ls_msg         TYPE usmd_s_message,
         lv_fieldname   TYPE bu_koinh,
         lv_acc_holder TYPE char20.
   FIELD-SYMBOLS:
     <lt_bank>        TYPE SORTED TABLE,
     <ls_bank>        TYPE any,
     <lv_acc_holder> TYPE any.
   io_model->get_changed_fields(
     IMPORTING	
       et_entity_fieldname =  DATA(lt_fieldname)               
   )
   .
   LOOP AT lt_fieldname INTO DATA(ls_fieldname).
     lv_fieldname = ls_fieldname-fieldname.
     IF lv_fieldname = 'KOINH'.
       lv_acc_holder = lv_fieldname.
     ENDIF.
   ENDLOOP.
   IF lv_acc_holder = 'KOINH'.
     io_model->read_entity_data_all(
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname      =       'BP_HEADER'           " Financial MDM: Field Name
        if_active        =         abap_false          " Financial MDM: General Indicator
    i_crequest       =            id_crequest          " Change Request
      IMPORTING
    et_message       =        lt_msg          " Messages
        et_data_entity   =      lt_data            " Data for Entity Types
    ).
     lt_bank_data = VALUE #( lt_data[ usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_BKDTL' struct = 'KATTR' ]-r_t_data  OPTIONAL ).
     IF lt_bank_data IS NOT INITIAL.
       ASSIGN lt_bank_data->* TO <lt_bank>.
       IF <lt_bank> IS ASSIGNED.
         LOOP AT <lt_bank> ASSIGNING <ls_bank>.
           ASSIGN COMPONENT 'KOINH' OF STRUCTURE <ls_bank> TO <lv_acc_holder>.
           IF <lv_acc_holder> IS ASSIGNED AND
              <lv_acc_holder> IS NOT INITIAL AND                        
             <lv_acc_holder> CA '~`!@#$%^&*()-_+={}[]|\:;"<,>.?/'.
             et_message = VALUE #( BASE et_message ( fieldname = 'KOINH' msgid = 'ZMDGS_MESSAGE_CLS' msgno = '002' msgty = 'E' ) ).
           ENDIF.
         ENDLOOP.
       ENDIF.
     ENDIF.
   ENDIF.
 ENDMETHOD.

entry.title: SAP MDG: Validation - Notes Mandatory
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great 🙂

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to enforce mandatory entry of Notes during master data processes. The validation logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via:
BADI:USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY.

This ensures that users provide the required notes, thereby improving data completeness, auditability, and compliance during master data creation and change activities.

Code:

DATA:
  lv_cr_number TYPE usmd_crequest,
  lv_crtype    TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
  lv_process   TYPE usmd_process.

DATA(lo_context) = cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context( ).

IF lo_context IS BOUND.
  CALL METHOD lo_context->get_attributes
    IMPORTING
      ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
      ev_crequest_type = lv_crtype
      ev_process       = lv_process.
ENDIF.

IF lv_crtype EQ 'ZSUCRTYPE'.
  DATA(lv_s_notes) = cl_usmd_conv_som_gov_api=>get_instance( )->get_notes( ).
       IF lv_s_notes IS INITIAL.
          APPEND cl_usmd_message=>convert_text2message(
          EXPORTING
          iv_message_text = 'Please Maintain Notes, It''s Mandatory !!!'.
          iv_message_type = 'E' ) to et_message.
       ENDIF.
ENDIF.

 

SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
